pioneers.name: Vannevar Bush, D.Eng.
pioneers.background: Vannevar Bush was born on March 11, 1890, in Everett, Massachusetts, United States. He is an American electrical engineer, science administrator, and inventor. During World War II he gained a notary for being the head of the Office of Scientific Research and Development that served a pivotal role in winning the war. After joining the MIT Electrical Engineering Department he went on to launch his own company, Raytheon, serve different companies, and invent different devices.
contributions: Creation of the Memex device that helps with hypertext

pioneers.name: Doug Englebart, Ph.D.
pioneers.background: Doug Englebart was born on January 30, 1925, in Portland, Oregon, United States. He studied electrical engineering at Oregon State University and even served in U.S. Navy as an electronics and radar technician overseas. Later on, in life, he worked as an engineer and investor and gain a notary for the creation of the mouse which become a staple in today’s society. Even though trackpads and touch screens are prevalent the mouse pad is more commonly used, showing the significance of Doug’s invention.
contributions: Development of basic graphical user interface (GUI)

pioneers.name: Ted Nelson, Ph.D.
pioneers.background: Ted Nelson was born on June, 17, 1937 in Chicago, Illinois, United States. He created the hypertext and hypermedia term to refer to features in computerized information system. He derived the link term to refer to logical connection relating to hyperlink. Also, books published by Ted Nelson from 1964 to 1980 Bush’s books were transposed by Ted Nelson that incorporated automated crossing-referencing into the computer context.

pioneers.name: Steve Jobs
pioneers.background: Steve Jobs was born on February 24, 1955 in San Francisco, California, United States. He is notable innovator of the personal computer era. Along with Steve Wozniak, Jobs co-founded Apple Inc. that was formed in 1976, and he later turned it into a telecommunications industry titan. He oversaw the introduction of ground-breaking products like the iPod and the iPhone, which are widely regarded as genius inventions. Due Steve Jobs leadership was able to establish themselves as prompt company worth over a billion dollar.

pioneers.name: Steve Wozniak
pioneers.background: Steve Wozniak was born on August 11, 1950 in San Jose, California, United States. He is electronics engineer and along with Steve Jobs founded Apple Computer. Also, credited with the invention of the personal computer, which is a computer that was designed to use by only one individual. The invention of the Apple I was revolutionary product that helped establish themselves as prominent company in the industry.

pioneers.name: Tim Berners-Lee, KBE
pioneers.background: Tim Berners-Lee was born on June 8, 1955 in London, England. In 1989, he created the World Wide Web. He is a co-founder and CTO of the tech start-up Inrupt.com, which uses, promotes, and works to advance the open-source Solid platform. Solid challenges several presumptions about how the web must function in order to provide people ownership and agency over their data.

pioneers.name: Marc Andreessen
pioneers.background: Marc Andreessen was born on July 9, 1971, in Cedar Falls, Iowa, United States. He is a software developer that credited notable technology such as Mosaic and Netscape. Both Mosaic and Netscape is credited with transforming the internet by changing the way information is exchange Additionally, Netscape was very beneficial to the internet as it allowed individuals and businesses to exchange information over the internet. Also, went on to run a successful venture capital firm based in Silicon Valley, whose successful bets include Instagram, Oculus VR, and GitHub.

pioneers.name: Eric Bina
pioneers.background: Eric Bina was born on October 25, 1964, in Champaign, Illinois, United States. Along with Marc Andreessen, he is the co-founder of the web browser Mosaic and Netscape. Both Mosaic and Netscape are credited with transforming the internet by changing the way information is exchanged. In 1995, hard paid off as he was awarded the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) software systems award for his contribution to the world wide web.
